Knowledge Point: Tuatschin has \isi{verb-second} syntax, which means that if no element of the sentence occurs before the \isi{subject}, the \isi{subject} precedes the verb as in (\ref{ex:sov1}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: As shown in \sectref{sec:4.2.2}, the \isi{indirect object} usually precedes the \isi{direct object} (\ref{ex:indir1}).
Content 1: \gll Quèl vès lu aun da pijè [da té] [al pustrètsch dal piartg tga té vèvas partgirau]. | \gls DEM.M.SG have.COND.3SG then still COMP pay.INF DAT 2SG DEF.M.SG money of.DEF.M.SG pig REL 2SG have.IMPF.2SG look_after.PTCP.UNM | \glt `This one should still pay you the money for the pig you had looked after.'

Knowledge Point: If there is an element that precedes the \isi{subject}, the \isi{subject} is moved after the finite verb as in (\ref{ex:sov2}) and (\ref{ex:sov4}).
Content 1: \gll [\textbf{Avaun} \textbf{in} \textbf{pèr} \textbf{jamnas}] … èr’ [\textbf{ju}] gjù Locarno~[...]. | \gls before INDEF.M.SG couple week.F.PL … COP.IMPF.1SG 1SG down PN | \glt `A couple of weeks ago … I was in Locarno [...].'
Content 2: \gll [...] a [\textbf{sjantar}] va [{\textbf{ju}}] … cumprau in zacù̱n. | \gls … and after have.PRS.1SG 1SG … buy.PTCP.UNM INDEF.M.SG second | \glt \sectref{sec:8.7}) | '

Knowledge Point: The coordinating conjunctions ábar `but' (\ref{ex:sov3}) and dantaun (\ref{ex:sov5}) `however' do not trigger \isi{subject inversion}. In contrast, api and its shorter form pi `and, and then' do trigger it (\ref{ex:sov3}, \ref{ex:aapi} and \ref{ex:aapi1}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Ju vagnès schòn, \textbf{dantaun} \textbf{vuṣ} \textbf{vajs} taun tschùf ajn tgèsa. | \gls 1SG come.COND.1SG really however 2PL have.PRS.2PL so_much dirt in house | \glt `I would come, of course, but you have so much dirt in your house.'
Content 5: \gll \textbf{Pi} ṣè `\textbf{l} vajramájn staus lò. | \gls then be.PRS.3SG 3SG.M true.F.SG.ADV remain.PTCP.M.SG there | \glt `And it [= the swan] really stayed there.'

Knowledge Point: After subordinating conjunctions there is no \isi{subject inversion} (\ref{ex:subconj1}--\ref{ex:subconj3}).
Content 1: \gll La buéba ò détg \textbf{tg'} \textbf{èla} \textbf{ségi} bétga \textbf{ida} vòluntárjamajn, èla stuévi ira. | \gls DEF.F.SG girl have.PRS.3SG say.PTCP.UNM COMP 3SG be.PRS.SBJV.3SG NEG go.PTCP.F.SG voluntary.ADV 3SG.F must.IMPF.SBJV.3SG go.INF | \glt `The girl said that she didn'

Knowledge Point: If a \isi{subject} which would normally be inverted is focalised, it may occur preverbally, as quèls `these' in (\ref{ex:subconj4}).
Content 1: \gll A lur scha `l vèṣ ussa pagljau par èxè̱mpal in grép tga vès pudju bétar èl, scha \textbf{quèls} fùssan grat schulaj gjù ajl’ aua, ajl lac. | \gls and then if 3SG.M have.COND.3SG now hit.PTCP.UNM for example.M.SG INDEF.M.SG rock REL have.COND.3SG can.PTCP.UNM throw.INF 3SG.M CORR DEM.M.PL be.COND.3PL immediately fall_rapidly.PTCP.M.PL down into.DEF.F.SG water into.DEF.M.SG lake | \glt `And then if it [the load] hit a rock which could have thrown it down, these [= the mules] would have immediately fallen down rapidly into the water, into the lake.'

Knowledge Point: The inverted \isi{subject} is not immediately adjacent to the verb, and in (\ref{ex:sagir1}) sagir `sure' is located immediately after the verb.
Content 1: \gll [...] avaun nus \textbf{èra} \textbf{sagir} \textbf{al} \textbf{tgavrè} èra schòn jus culas tgauras, lèz mava lu èra. | \gls … before 1PL be.IMPF.3SG sure DEF.M.SG goatherd also already go.PTCP.M.SG with.DEF.F.PL goat.PL DEM.M.SG go.IMPF.3SG then also | \glt `[...] before us the goatherd had certainly already gone with the goats, he also used to go.'

Knowledge Point: However, some consultants reject the position of sagir in (\ref{ex:sagir1}). For them, sagir should be located between èra `also' and schòn `already'.
Content 1: \gll [...] avaun nus \textbf{èra} \textbf{sagir} \textbf{al} \textbf{tgavrè} èra schòn jus culas tgauras, lèz mava lu èra. | \gls … before 1PL be.IMPF.3SG sure DEF.M.SG goatherd also already go.PTCP.M.SG with.DEF.F.PL goat.PL DEM.M.SG go.IMPF.3SG then also | \glt `[...] before us the goatherd had certainly already gone with the goats, he also used to go.'

Knowledge Point: The \isi{subject pronoun} is usually obligatory in Tuatschin, but the \isi{omission of the subject} may occur in subordinated and coordinated clauses if it can be recovered from the context (\ref{ex:nosubj1} and \ref{ex:nosubj2}).
Content 1: \gll Avaun ina fjasta mavan \textbf{aj} … tialas … gjufnas … par nègla, partgé \longrule matévan sé sé la capjala … ina nègla. | \gls before INDEF.F.SG celebration go.IMPF.3PL 3PL … to.DEF.F.PL … young_woman.PL … for carnation.F.PL because SBJ put.IMPF.3PL up up DEF.F.SG hat … INDEF.F.SG carnation | \glt `Before a celebration they would go … to the … girls for carnations, because they would put … a carnation on their hat.'

Knowledge Point: Polar questions are characterised by a rising intonation and \isi{subject inversion} (\ref{ex:interr1}).
Content 1: \gll Gè, sùnd ju ajn tju taritòri, distùrb’ ju té? | \gls yes COP.PRS.1SG 1SG in POSS.2SG.M.SG territory disturb.PRS.1SG 1SG 2SG | \glt `Yes, am I in your territory, do I disturb you?'

Knowledge Point: Content questions require the presence of an \isi{interrogative word} and, like polar questions, exhibit \isi{subject inversion}. \isi{Interrogative pronouns} are cu/cura `when' (\ref{ex:int4}), cù `how' (\ref{ex:int8}), dacù `why' (\ref{ex:int10}), danùndar `where from' (\ref{ex:int11}), núa `where' (\ref{ex:int3}), partgé(j) `why' (\ref{ex:int5}), tgé(j) `what' (\ref{ex:int2}), tgé(j)nín/tgé(j)nina `which one'(\ref{ex:int7}), tgi `who' (\ref{ex:int1}). The \isi{interrogative determiner} is tgé(j) `which, what'(\ref{ex:int6}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Cu} ṣè la vagnida? | \gls when be.PRS.3SG 3SG.F come.PTCP.F.SG | \glt `When did she come?'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Cù} détsch ju? Gjù Sardégna? | \gls how say.PRS.1SG 1SG down PN | \glt `How do I say? Down Sardinia?'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Dacù} as té fatg quaj? | \gls how have.PRS.2SG 2SG do.PTCP.UNM DEM.UNM | \glt `Why did you do this?'
Content 4: \gll \textbf{Danùndar} èn èls vagní? | \gls where_from be.PRS.3PL 3PL come.PTCP.M.PL | \glt `Where did they come from?'
Content 5: \gll \textbf{Núa} ajs staus? | \gls where be.PRS.2SG COP.PTCP.M.SG | \glt `Where have you been?'
Content 6: \gll \textbf{Pr̩tgéj} fas quaj? | \gls why do.PRS.2SG DEM.UNM | \glt `Why do you do this?'
Content 7: \gll \textbf{Tgéj} lajn fá avaun c' í a raschlá? | \gls what want.PRS.1PL do.INF before REL go.INF COMP rake.INF | \glt `What shall we do before going to rake?'
Content 8: \gll \textbf{Tgéjnina} as cumprau? | \gls which_one have.PRS.2SG buy.PTCP.UNM | \glt `Which one did you buy?'
Content 9: \gll \textbf{Tgi} ò malagjau quaj malètg? | \gls who have.PRS.3SG paint.PTCP.UNM DEM.M.SG picture | \glt `Who painted this picture?'
Content 10: \gll \textbf{Tgéj} \textbf{tgamiṣcha} as cumprau? | \gls which shirt.F.SG have.PRS.2SG buy.PTCP.UNM | \glt `Which shirt did you buy?'

Knowledge Point: Imperative sentences may or may not lack a \isi{subject}. If they have one, it may precede (\ref{ex:imp.precede}) or follow the \isi{verb} (\ref{ex:imp.follow}).
Content 1: \gll «\textbf{Té} \textbf{nò} lu vidòr ússa. Lò, quèsta sèra \textbf{dòrma} lu \textbf{bigja} ajn lò.» | \gls 2SG come.IMP.2SG then down now there DEM.F.SG evening sleep.IMP.2SG then NEG in there | \glt `Come down here now. There, don’t sleep up there this evening.»'
Content 2: \gll Ah uòn \textbf{nò} \textbf{té} ajnta Pardatsch. | \gls eh this_year GO.IMP.2SG 2SG into PN | \glt `Ah, this year go to Pardatsch.'

Knowledge Point: There are some more elements that may precede an imperative: an \isi{indirect object} (\ref{ex:impdat}) and the adverb mù `only, just' (\ref{ex:impmu}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In \isi{prohibitive} sentences, the negator bétga and its allomorphs precede the imperative (\ref{ex:betga1}). But if some elements precede the imperative as in (\ref{ex:imp.precede}), the negator follows it.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Bétg} tumaj! | \gls NEG be_afraid.IMP.2PL | \glt `Don’t be afraid!'
Content 2: \gll «\textbf{Té} \textbf{nò} lu vidòr ússa. Lò, quèsta sèra \textbf{dòrma} lu \textbf{bigja} ajn lò.» | \gls 2SG come.IMP.2SG then down now there DEM.F.SG evening sleep.IMP.2SG then NEG in there | \glt `Come down here now. There, don’t sleep up there this evening.»'

Knowledge Point: Reflexive verbs use the prefix sa- in the imperative (\ref{ex:imprefl}) as in all other tenses, moods, and non-finite categories.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Sapartgiraj} dals bètlars cu tgi vòn a tgavaj. | \gls REFL.beware.IMP.2PL of.DEF.M.PL beggar.PL when REL.3PL go.PRS.3SG on horse.M.SG | \glt `Beware of the beggars when they ride.'

Knowledge Point: If a \isi{stative verb} forms an imperative, \isi{subjunctive mood} is used, like vajas `have \textsc{sbjv.2pl}' in (\ref{ex:impsubj}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Vajas} quitaus cu vus majṣ ṣur la lingja via … dal dṣùc, dal zùc.» | \gls have.IMP.2PL worry.M.PL when 2PL go.PRS.2PL over DEF.F.SG line over … of.DEF.M.SG train.M.SG of.DEF.M.SG train | \glt `Be careful when you cross the railway line, the railway line.'

Knowledge Point: The \isi{hortative} is formed with the first person plural present of the verb \textit{\isi{vulaj}} `want', lajn `let's', and the \isi{infinitive} (\ref{ex:imp.hort1} and \ref{ex:imp.hort2}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Lajn} \textbf{còj} quèla tgarn. | \gls IMP.1PL cook.INF DEM.F.SG meat | \glt `Let'

Knowledge Point: Optative meaning is conveyed by the subjunctive (\ref{ex:opt1}), as the stative verbs do.
Content 1: \gll Djus \textbf{banadèschi} a \textbf{carschjanti}! | \gls God bless.PRS.SBJV.3SG and thrive.PRS.SBJV.3SG | \glt `May God bless [it] and make [it] thrive!'

Knowledge Point: Exclamative sentences are formed with the interrogative pronouns cù `how' (\ref{ex:exclcu}) or tgéj `what' (\ref{ex:excltgej}).
Content 1: \gll Jeusas, \textbf{cù} quaj briṣcha! | \gls EXCL how DEM.UNM burn.PRS.3SG | \glt `Jee, how it burns!'
Content 2: \gll Míu frá ṣchèva aun ér: «\textbf{Tgé} té pùs!» | \gls POSS.1SG.M.SG brother say.IMPF.3SG still yesterday what 2SG can.PRS.2SG | \glt `My brother said not later than yesterday: «[Incredible that you still] have the strength [to do that]!»'

Knowledge Point: In Tuatschin, \isi{reflexive voice} is formed with the prefix sa- in all finite and non-\isi{finite categories}. The Sursilvan norm stipulates that the \isi{auxiliary verb} be \isi{èssar} `be', and in the corpus it is mostly so (\ref{ex:refessar1} and \ref{ex:refessar2}); however, vaj `have' is not rare (\ref{ex:refvaj1}--\ref{ex:refvaj3}).\footnote{According to the \DRG{1}{568}, the choice of esser as \isi{auxiliary verb} for reflexives in Sursilvan is due to the demand of Sursilvan grammarians since the 18th century. Nowadays speakers seek to conform to this claim, but in spoken Sursilvan, one still can find haver as \isi{auxiliary} for \isi{reflexive verbs}, as is the case in Tuatschin.}
Content 1: Not found
Content 3: \gll [...] a \textbf{vèṣ} è bitga \textbf{sa-fatg} \textbf{ajn} zatgé spazjal. | \gls … and have.COND.1SG also NEG REFL-do.PTCP.UNM in something special.M.SG | \glt `[...] and I wouldn’t have noticed anything either.'
Content 4: \gll Als fildiròms \textbf{òn} \textbf{sa-pagljau} ajnt. | \gls DEF.M.PL wire.PL have.PRS.3PL REFL-touch.PTCP.UNM in | \glt `The wires touched each other.'

Knowledge Point: \isi{Reciprocal voice} is formed with in ... l'autar / ina ... l'autra `the one ... the other' (\ref{ex:recip1} and \ref{ex:recip2}).
Content 1: \gll Ad èlas duaṣ ábar ancanùsché̱van … \textbf{in}’ \textbf{l}’ \textbf{autra} ad ju lu halt bégja. | \gls and 3PL.F two.F.PL but know.IMPF.3PL … one.F.SG DEF.F.SG other and 1SG then in_fact NEG | \glt `But these two already knew … each other but I didn’t.'
Content 2: \gll Nus vajn dau in cùdisch \textbf{in} \textbf{da} \textbf{l}' \textbf{autar}. | \gls 1PL have.PRS.1PL give.PTCP.UNM INDEF.M.SG book one.ONE.M DAT DEF.M.SG other | \glt `We gave each other a book.'

Knowledge Point: \isi{Causative voice} is formed with \isi{fá} ‘make’ (\ref{ex:causfa1}--\ref{ex:causfa4}) and \textit{\isi{schè}/schá}\footnote{Schá is the \ili{Standard Sursilvan} form.} `have something done, let' (\ref{ex:causscha1} and \ref{ex:causscha2}) followed by an \isi{infinitive}. The causee follows the second \isi{verb} and occurs as a \isi{direct object}, which is shown by the use of the \isi{direct object pronoun} mè (vs da mé for the \isi{indirect object}) in (\ref{ex:causfa5}). Examples (\ref{ex:causfa4}) and (\ref{ex:causfa5}) furthermore show that their construction involves two direct objects.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Ju \textbf{fétsch} \textbf{fá} al cusunz in pèr tgautschas pr̩ èl. | \gls 1SG make.PRS.1SG do.INF DEF.M.SG tailor INDEF.M.SG pair trousers.M.PL for 3SG.M | \glt `I have the tailor make a pair of trousers for him.'
Content 3: \gll I \textbf{schèvan} \textbf{luvrá} fétg. | \gls 3PL let.IMPF.3PL work.INF much | \glt `They had [us] work a lot.'
Content 4: \gll Èl ò \textbf{schau} \textbf{savaj} la règína quaj. | \gls 3SG.M have.PRS.3SG let.PTCP.UNM know.INF DEF.F.SG queen DEM | \glt `He let the queen know this.'
Content 5: \gll Èl \textbf{fò} \textbf{fá} \textbf{mè} in pèr tgautschas pr̩ èl. | \gls 3SG.M make.PRS.3SG do.INF 1SG.DO INDEF.M.SG pair trousers.M.PL for 3SG.M | \glt `He has me make a pair of trousers for him.'
Content 6: \gll Ju \textbf{fétsch} \textbf{fá} al cusunz in pèr tgautschas pr̩ èl. | \gls 1SG make.PRS.1SG do.INF DEF.M.SG tailor INDEF.M.SG pair trousers.M.PL for 3SG.M | \glt `I have the tailor make a pair of trousers for him.'
Content 7: \gll Èl \textbf{fò} \textbf{fá} \textbf{mè} in pèr tgautschas pr̩ èl. | \gls 3SG.M make.PRS.3SG do.INF 1SG.DO INDEF.M.SG pair trousers.M.PL for 3SG.M | \glt `He has me make a pair of trousers for him.'

Knowledge Point: A \isi{dynamic passive} is formed with the verb vagní ‘come’ and the participle (\ref{ex:pass.dyn1}--\ref{ex:pass.dyn5}). A \isi{stative passive} is formed with the verb \isièssar `be' and the participle (\ref{ex:pass.stat1}--\ref{ex:pass.stat3}). In both cases the participle agrees with the patient \isi{subject} if it precedes the \isi{passive} construction.
Content 1: \gll [...] \textbf{als} \textbf{tiars} èn \textbf{vagní} \textbf{pri} òd stával a \textbf{purtaj} navèn. | \gls … DEF.M.PL animal.PL be.PRS.3PL PASS.PTCP.M.PL take.PTCP.M.PL out_of barn and bring.PTCP.M.PL away | \glt `The animals were taken out of the barn and brought away.'
Content 2: \gll [...] lu èra quaj … craju, sjat fjastas … tga \textbf{vagnéva} … \textbf{fátg} \textbf{parada}. | \gls … then COP.IMPF.3SG DEM.UNM … believe.PRS.1SG.1SG seven celebration.F.PL … REL PASS.IMPF.3SG … do.PTCP.UNM parade.F.SG | \glt `[...] then there were …, I believe, seven celebrations … when they would … prepare a parade.'
Content 3: \gll A qu' \textbf{èra} schòn \textbf{dau} bjè \textbf{najv} ad èran bigj’ aun vagní vidò culs tiars. | \gls and DEM.UNM PASS.IMPF.3SG already give.PTCP.UNM much snow.F.SG and be.IMPF.3PL NEG yet come.PTCP.M.PL down with.DEF.M.PL animal.PL | \glt `And there was already a lot of snow and they hadn’t come back down with the animals yet.'

Knowledge Point: Place names are considered to have no \isi{gender}, hence the use of the \isi{unmarked} form of the participle (\ref{ex:pass.dyn6}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: If the \isi{agent} of a \isi{passive} construction is mentioned, it is introduced by da (\ref{ex:pass.dyn7} and \ref{ex:pass.dyn8}). Whether da corresponds to the preposition or to the \isi{dative marker} is not easy to decide. The only case where there is a difference between the two da's is the \isi{first person singular object pronoun}, which is either mè (accusative and after prepositions) or mé (\isi{dative marker}). As noted in \sectref{sec:3.5}, some speakers prefer using the \isi{pronoun} mé (dative), whereas others use mè (accusative) in order to introduce the \isi{agent} of a \isi{passive} construction.
Content 1: \gll [...] quèls mulissiars, quèls ah fagèvan lu quasi las préfatschèntas, né, né tg’ èran ... cumissunaj \textbf{da} \textbf{quèls} ah \textbf{martgadònts} grònṣ da la bassa, né. | \gls … DEM.M.PL negotiator.PL DEM.M.PL eh do.IMPF.3PL then so_to_speak DEF.F.PL intermediate_trade.PL right or COMP PASS.IMPF.3PL … commission.PTCP.M.PL DAT DEM.M.PL eh businessman.PL big.PL of DEF.F.SG «lowlands» right | \glt `[...] These negotiators, they would so to speak do the intermediate trade, or they were ... commissioned by the big businessmen from outside the Grisons, right?'
Content 2: \gll Al baghètg è vagnuṣ bagagjauṣ \textbf{da} \textbf{mju} \textbf{auc}. | \gls DEF.M.SG building be.PRS.3SG PASS.PTCP.M.SG build.PTCP.M.SG DAT POSS.1SG.M.SG uncle | \glt `The building has been built by my uncle.'
